==Japanese==
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|モグラ}}
{{wikipedia|Mole (animal)}}
[[Image:Close-up of mole.jpg|thumb|250px|{{PAGENAME}} (''mogura'', ''moguramochi'', ''mugura'', ''muguramochi'', ''uguramochi'', ''uguromochi'', ''ugoromochi'', ''doryū''): a '''[[mole]]'''.]]

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=もぐら}}
A surface analysis suggests a derivation from the verb {{m|ja|潜る|tr=moguru||to go underneath or into something, such as water or the ground}}.

However, the modern ''mogura'' reading appears to be relatively recent. The older form of this noun was variously ''ugoromochi'', ''uguromochi'', or ''uguramochi'', deriving from now-obsolete verb {{m|ja|墳つ|tr=ugumotsu</i>, <i>uguromotsu</i>, <i>ugomotsu</i>, <i>ugoromotsu||to become a pile or small hill, as of soil}}. This verb itself appears to be a compound deriving from obsolete {{m|ja|穿ぐ|tr=ugu||to dig a hole|pos=a {{m|ja|下二段|tr=shimo nidan}} or “lower bigrade” conjugation verb}} + {{m|ja|持つ|tr=motsu||to have in hand; to carry, to bring}}, with an underlying idea of “that which digs and brings up the dirt [to form a molehill]”. The verb ''ugu'' had a {{m|ja|連体形|tr=rentaikei||attributive form}} of ''uguru'', attaching only to nouns, suggesting that the original parsing of this might have been “digging bringer”.

The shift in sound from ''uguru'' to the variants ''uguro'' and ''ugoro'' may be a reflection of the morpheme ''-ro'' that appears in numerous words indicating a hollow interior. Compare {{m|ja|空ろ|tr=utsuro||a hollow, an emptiness}}, {{m|ja|室|tr=muro||a room; an excavated dwelling on the side of a mountain}}, {{m|ja|袋|tr=fukuro||a bag}}, possibly even {{m|ja|所|tr=tokoro||a place}}. The ''ugoromochi'' reading appears in the {{m|ja|本草和名|tr=Honzō Wamyō}}, a [[pharmacopoeia]] compiled some time in the years 901-923.

The ''uguramochi'' variant was either dialectal, or a later development.

With the beginning of the [[w:Edo period|Edo period]] and the shift in the political and cultural center to Edo, ''uguramochi'' was superseded by the eastern dialectal form ''muguramochi''. The 1603 {{m|ja|日葡辞書|tr=Nippo Jisho||Japanese-Portuguese Dictionary}} lists one variant as ''mugura'', indicating that the ''mochi'' portion could be dropped. This ''mugura'' then became ''mogura'', possibly influenced by the verb {{m|ja|潜る|tr=moguru}}.

===Etymology 7===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=うごろもち}}

Derived as the {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|墳つ|tr=ugumotsu</i>, <i>uguromotsu</i>, <i>ugomotsu</i>, <i>ugoromotsu||to become a pile or small hill, as of soil}}. See above for further details.
